metadata.case_name: Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited v. Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh

facts.text: The appellant, Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited, is a textile mill and its factory is situate at Jalgaon.
The respondent, Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh, represents the employees of the appellant-Company.

The respondent on behalf of the employees issued a notice to the appellant under s. 42(2) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, demanding payment of reasonable bonus for the period from January 1, 1955 to December 31, 1955.
Negotiations in this regard having failed, the respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the said Act for arbitration of the dispute arising out of the said notice.

The arbitrator, i.e. the Industrial Court, following the Full Bench Formula, ascertained the surplus to be Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting the prior charges from the gross profits of the Company, but it did not give any credit to the rehabilitation amount apart from the statutory depreciation.

The Industrial Court estimated the amount required for rehabilitation at Rs. 60 lakhs out of this amount it deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves and the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over a period of 15 years gave the figure of Rs. 60,000 as the amount that should be set apart for the year in question for rehabilitation.
As the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, it came to the conclusion that the Company would not be entitled to any allocation as a prior charge for rehabilitation.
After excluding the said item of rehabilitation, it fixed the surplus in a sum of Rs. 2.20 lakhs and awarded to the employees four months basic wages as bonus.

The Industrial Court observed: 'It is true that until some amount is required to be spent for rehabilitation, replacement or modernization, reserves must be used as working capital, but Shri Vimadalals argument overlooks that the amount required to be spent for rehabilitation over a course of 15 years is not required to be spent all at once, but by instalments over a long period.'

In the written-statement filed by the appellant before the Industrial Court, no specific allegation is made that the reserves were utilised as working capital, though in its statement of calculations the said reserves were not excluded from the amount claimed towards rehabilitation.
The respondent also in its statement did not deny the said fact, but in its statement of calculations it did not deduct the reserves from the rehabilitation amount.

The evidence of the General Superintendent of the appellant-Company does not deposed that the Company used the reserves as working capital nor does the said witness seek to prove either the balance-sheet or any extract taken therefrom.
There is no reserve which has been reasonably earmarked to discharge a contractual or statutory obligation. The Court is only concerned with general reserves.

legal_issues.text: What extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained.
Whether the reserves were used as working capital during the bonus year in question.
What is the scope of the finding of the Industrial Court in regard to the use of reserves as working capital.
The procedure to be followed by Industrial Courts for ascertaining whether reserves have been used as working capital or reasonably earmarked.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Industrial Court accepted the position that the reserves were used as working capital, but deducted the said amount from the amount required for rehabilitation on a wrong and unjustified assumption that, as the amounts so required would be spent for rehabilitation over a course of 15 years by instalments, the temporary user of the said reserves would not affect the question as they would be released in part or in whole in future years.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Decided cases and principle governing the ascertainment of the amount for rehabilitation purposes

petitioner_arguments.text: The balance-sheet discloses that the entire reserves have been used as working capital and that the respondent did not canvass this position in the statement filed by it before the Industrial Court.

respondent_arguments.text: The Industrial Court only assumed that the reserves had been utilised as working capital, as in the view taken by it, it did not in the least matter whether the reserves were so utilised or not and that, even if that view was wrong, the appellant could not succeed, unless it proved by relevant and acceptable evidence that the reserves were so utilised and that it did not place before the Industrial Court any such evidence to prove that fact.

court_reasoning.text: The aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is not sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the State of affairs in that year is the guiding factor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If in a subsequent year any part of the reserves used as working capital is released, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year.

court_reasoning.text: The reserves which have been used as working capital shall not be deducted from the amount fixed for rehabilitation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: This result does not advance the case of the appellant, unless it is able to prove by admissible evidence that it has used the reserves as working capital during the bonus year in question.

court_reasoning.text: Before actually awarding an appropriate amount in respect of rehabilitation for the bonus year certain deductions have to be made... general reserves available to the employer... reserves which have already been reasonably earmarked for specific purposes of the industry are, however, not taken into account in this connection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The mere availability of reserves or the simple earmarking for specific purposes would be [not] sufficient to claim the said amounts as deductions.

court_reasoning.text: Before a particular reserve can [be] deducted from the rehabilitation amount it must be established that it has been reasonably earmarked for a binding purpose or the whole or a part of it has been used as working capital.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

court_reasoning.text: The balance-sheet, without its being proved by a person competent to do so, cannot prove that any reserves have been utilised as working capital.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.

court_reasoning.text: Industrial Courts may conveniently follow the procedure prescribed in Order XIX of the Code of Civil Procedure so that both the parties may have full opportunity to establish their respective cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principles of equity and justice demand that tribunals should weigh with great care the evidence adduced by the management as well as by the labour to ascertain every sub-item that goes into or is subtracted from the item of rehabilitation.

holdings.text: Reserves may be deducted from rehabilitation amount only if reasonably earmarked for binding purpose or used as working capital, proved by evidence.
The Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus as balance Rs. 60,000 < statutory depreciation Rs. 83,639.
Industrial Courts must insist on proof of use of reserves as working capital, following Order XIX CPC procedure, giving opportunity for cross-examination.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Restated principle on deductions for rehabilitation: breakdown value, depreciation, general reserves available, reserves not reasonably earmarked for specific purposes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Balance-sheet relied upon for proving reserves used as working capital where no objection urged; emphasizes need for proof.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Company Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Accepted affidavit on use of depreciation reserve as working capital but reserved right for future cross-examination.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anil Starch Products Ltd. v. Ahmedabad Chemical Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Accepted affidavit and witness evidence on use of reserves as working capital where not challenged in cross-examination; reserved future rights.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice for bonus demand; reference for arbitration; powers of Industrial Court for proof of facts, summoning witnesses, production of documents.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for proof by affidavits with opportunity for cross-examination to be followed by Industrial Courts for rehabilitation claims.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Industrial Court's award of bonus, finding no proof that reserves were used as working capital, thus rightly deducting Rs. 51 lakhs from rehabilitation amount, leading to no additional allocation beyond depreciation, and surplus of Rs. 2.20 lakhs supporting 4 months' basic wages bonus.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; bonus award to employees upheld

key_quotes.text: "Before a particular reserve can deducted from the rehabilitation amount it must be established that it has been reasonably earmarked for a binding purpose or the whole or a part of it has been used as working capital"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on conditions for deducting reserves from rehabilitation.

key_quotes.text: "The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes burden of proof on employer.

key_quotes.text: "In view of the importance of the item of rehabilitation... principles of equity and justice demand that an Industrial Court should insist upon a clear proof of the same"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes procedural fairness in bonus disputes.
